title: Discus Distances: Parallel Boxplots
question_text:
At a state track & field meet, $100$ boys and $100$ girls competed in the discus throw. The parallel boxplots below show the distribution of the distances the discus was thrown by each competitor. Note that these boxplots are regular boxplots, not modified boxplots.
Created for Albert.io. Copyright 2016. All rights reserved.

All of the following statements can be justified by the boxplots EXCEPT:

choices.text:
At least
25
%
of the boys did better than all of the girls.
The IQR was smaller for the girls than for the boys.
The girls had at least one high outlier, but the boys had no high outliers.

The median for the boys was about
50
%
higher than the median for girls.

solution:
We can attempt to verify each statement in order to determine which choice is not justified by the boxplots.

Keep in mind that a boxplot divides the data into four sections each of which contains about
25
%
of the observations.

About
25
%
of the observations will fall between the minimum value and the
Q
1
value (found below the first vertical segment in the boxplot).
About
25
%
of the observations will fall between the
Q
1
value and the median (found below the second vertical segment).
About
25
%
of the observations will fall between the median and the
Q
3
value (found below the third vertical segment).
And about
25
%
of the observations will fall between the
Q
3
value and the maximum.

Since there may be several identical observations around each of these major values, the actual percentage may be a little bit more or a little bit less than
25
%
.

Choice 'A' can be justified by the boxplots. The maximum distance thrown by a girl can be estimated to be about
132
or
133
feet. However, the
Q
3
value for boys is higher at about
135
or
136
feet. At least
25
%
of the boys' distances are at the
Q
3
value or higher.

Choice 'B' can be justified by the boxplots. We can determine IQR as follows:

I
Q
R
=
Q
3
−
Q
1

Although we may need to estimate a bit, the following approximations are reasonable.

For girls:

Q
3
=
96

Q
1
=
81

I
Q
R
=
96
−
81
=
15

For boys:

Q
3
=
136

Q
1
=
112

I
Q
R
=
913
−
112
=
24

From these calculations, it is clear that the IQR is smaller for the girls' distribution than for the boys' distribution. However, we could also have established this fact visually by noticing that the box formed between the
Q
1
value and the
Q
3
value is smaller on the girls' boxplot than on the boys' boxplot.

Choice 'C' can be justified by the boxplots. First keep in mind that the boxplots are regular boxplots (which do not specifically show the existence of outliers). They are not modified boxplots (which would show the outliers separately as a dot or perhaps an asterisk). The fact that we are looking at a regular boxplot means that we have to do a little bit of work to determine whether or not outliers exist.

A high outlier is an observation that falls above
Q
3
+
1.5
I
Q
R
. Using the
Q
3
and IQR values calculated above, we can determine that for girls, a high outlier would be any value that is greater than
96
+
1.5
(
15
)
or greater than
118.5
.

Since the maximum distance for girls is greater than
130
and
130
is greater than
118.5
, we know that there is at least one high outlier for girls. For boys, a high outlier would be any value greater than
136
+
1.5
(
24
)
or greater than
172
. Since the maximum distance for boys is certainly less than
172
, we know that there are no high outliers for boys.

Choice 'D' can be justified by the boxplots. Since the values to the right of the median are more spread out than values to the left of the median for both distributions, we know that both distributions are skewed right.

Choice 'E' cannot be justified by the boxplots which means that it is the correct choice. For girls, the median is about
86
or
87
. Using the lower estimate,
50
%
of
86
is
43
. Then,
86
+
43
=
129
. If the median for the boys was about
50
%
higher than the median for girls, the median for boys would be about
129
.

However, the median for boys is really only about
121
or
122
. It is not
50
%
higher than the median for girls. NOTE: If we used the higher estimate for the median for girls, the median for boys would need to be at least
130.5
in order for the statement provided in Choice 'E' to be correct. In either case, this statement cannot be justified by the boxplots.
